Award.AwardTitle: A Smoothed Finite Element Method (SFEM) for Fluid-Structural Interaction Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Systems in nature and manmade often involves both fluids and solid structures. The behavior and characteristics of such a system are often affected by the interactions between the fluid flows and solid structures. Study of the fluid-structural interaction is of great importance to understand, design and control such systems, and also presents big technical challenges, due to the complexity in geometry of the systems and the coupling of multiple physics (nonlinear solid mechanics, and Navier-Stokes flows). This project aims to develop a Smoothed Finite Element Method (SFEM) for solving general fluid-structural interaction problems with complicated geometry for both fluid media and nonlinear solids undergoing large deformation. This is achieved by developing a set of techniques and properly designed combinations of these techniques based on essentially the weakened weak formulation that allows the use of a much more general functions for field approximation, including a certain class of discontinuous functions (in a proper G space). The formulations for both fluid flows and solid structures will be unified in the some framework of SFEM. The developed computational technique consists largely of 1) an SFEM-Solid solver for modeling the nonlinear and dynamic behavior of solids and structures; 2) an SFEM-Fluid solver for dynamic behavior of fluids; and 3) SFEM-FSI solver for dealing with effectively the coupling at the interfaces of the moving solids in the flowing fluid. The developed SFEM-FSI model is expected to have important "softening" effects so that it can work well with triangular/tetrahedral mesh that can be generated automatically, enabling automation in computation for complicated systems. For the interaction between the fluids and solids, ideas of the immersed boundary/finite element methods will be employed and modified for effectively dealing with the overlaid areas near the interfaces of the fluid media and solids, without re-meshing to generate the body-fitted mesh.

The proposed project is multidiscipline in nature across computational mathematics, fluid dynamics, structure mechanics, and biomechanics. The computational techniques developed in this project are expected to have a significant impact to all these related areas. In particular, the SFEM formulations for the fluid-structural interaction problems are expected to offer a profound new approach in solving complicated problems with coupled multi-physics. Once developed, the SFEM-FSI will be applicable in the modeling and simulation of a wide class of problems in science and engineering, such as flapping wings for special purpose aircrafts (quite, low speed, flapping wings) such as micro air vehicles (MAV), design of large span and flexible membrane structural systems, modeling blood flows in human hearts and vascular systems, etc. Because the SFEM-FSI allows the use of triangular/tetrahedral mesh, it enables automation-in-computation, and thus is expected to have a pervasive impact in significantly saving resources for manual operations in the meshing and re-meshing process. It is anticipated to change significantly the capability and applicability of the existing modeling and simulation software packages largely written in the past half a century based on the standard weak formulations. In addition, through this project students will be well-trained in the related STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) area important for the long-term and sustainable development of knowledge-based economy in the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supported by this NSF grant, the project team has developed a set of novel S-FEM techniques and a prototype computer software package for solving fluid-structural interaction (FSI) problems. It enables the use of unstructured using T-meshes [3-noded tetrahedral (T3) elements for 2D, and 4-noded hexahedral (T4) elements for 3D] that can be automatically generated for complex geometry. The major outcomes of this project consist of the following major items:

  1. S-FEM formulation, algorithms, and code have been developed for large deformation problems of elastic and hyperelastic soft materials, based on our past work. Some further advancements were made on 1) solution bound and nearly exact solution to nonlinear problems; 2) inclusion of bubble function (bES-FEM) for total elimination of the volumetric locking; 3) analysis of stability, convergence and accuracy of bES-FEM and bFS-FEM for nearly incompressible materials; 3) adaptive singular ES-FEM for singular field of arbitrary order; 4) extension to crystal plasticity problems; 4) thermos-elastic cracking; and 5) extension to saturated porous media.
  2. For the first time, S-FEM has been developed for solving fluid dynamics problems. A S-FEM is formulated for incompressible fluids that are common in various engineering systems. The new S-FEM fluid solver uses the   Characteristic-Based Split (CBS) scheme to stabilize the solution in dealing with the coupled effects of convection and diffusion. This new S-FEM fluid solver works well with good accuracy and convergence, and it is a valuable alternative to the standard FEM for fluids. Moreover, when investigating the stabilization schemes for S-FEM, we have further devised a novel Characteristic-Based Penalty scheme using a selective node-based gradient smoothing operations, which worked well for the S-FEM formulation.
  3. A novel IS-FEM_FSI, where S-FEM is used for both fluids and solids, has been formulated, based on the immerse techniques for coupling of the fluids and heavily deformed moving solids. Verifications and validations of this newly developed IS-FEM_FSI have also been carried out. A number of techniques to enhance the efficiency of our IS-FEM_FSI have been developed, including the octree searching and point locating strategies that can significantly reduce the computational time for the information transfer on the FSI interfaces. In addition, multithreading has been implemented in our S-FEM algorithms.
  4. Finally, an IS-FEM_FSI code has been developed. The current code is capable of solving FSI problems with millions of fluid nodes with deformable structure immersed within, on a desktop computer. As a typical demonstration, we have successfully applied our IS-FEM_FSI code to simulate the hummingbird flapping process when it is hovering, with a relative large-scale model of about 2.5 millions of nodes. A video-clip of a computer simulated flapping hummingbird during hovering can be found at the PI’s webpage: http://www.ase.uc.edu/~liugr/. It shows not only the complex airflows structure around the bird, but also the stresses built on its wings that may undergo extremely large movement and deformation.

The developed IS-FEM_FSI offers a novel technology for simulating computationally fluid-structural interaction problems, based on the S-FEM technology. It is an important addition and advancement from the currently widely used FEM technology. All these techniques developed in the project have either have been, are or will be published in international journals and conferences.  

The societal impact of this project is mainly on education of various levels. During this project one postdoc (part time) and three graduate students (part time) have been trained in this area important for the development of knowledge-based economy in US. In addition, one Co-op project has been offered to one of UC’s undergraduate students to participant in research work. This Co-op project has produced a US Patent that has been filed (provisional). Moreover, the outcome of this project will be used in the PI’s courses in the university at both undergraduate and graduate levels, aiming for long term and much broader educational outcomes. One seminar has been delivered at the Mason High School to generate interest in the young. The techniques, data and publications generated in the project has already been and will continuously be released to the general public and made available online for easy access. Currently, video demonstrations are made available at the PI’s public webpage http://www.ase.uc.edu/~liugr/, together with other related works by the team. The PI has made substantial effort to best-maintain his Google Scholar page. The page is now constantly updated automatically by Google and vetted by the PI, so that the data is current and kept as accurate as possible. The list of constantly updated publications (including those from this project) can be openly found at any time at https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=uTsv5BcAAAAJ&hl=en. In addition, efforts will also be made to possibly transfer our S-FEM and IS-FEM_FSI technology to software developers.


Last Modified: 11/02/2016
Modified by: Gui-Rong Liu

Image
  • A hovering hummingbird is simulated using our IS-FEM_FSI technology. Airflow over the bird body, and the stresses on the wings of the bird are shown.
    GR Liu
    Copyrighted
    Gui-Rong Liu
    Hovering Hummingbird
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Supported by this NSF grant, the project team has developed a set of novel S-FEM techniques and a prototype computer software package for solving fluid-structural interaction (FSI) problems. It enables the use of unstructured using T-meshes [3-noded tetrahedral (T3) elements for 2D, and 4-noded hexahedral (T4) elements for 3D] that can be automatically generated for complex geometry. The major outcomes of this project consist of the following major items: S-FEM formulation, algorithms, and code have been developed for large deformation problems of elastic and hyperelastic soft materials, based on our past work. Some further advancements were made on 1) solution bound and nearly exact solution to nonlinear problems; 2) inclusion of bubble function (bES-FEM) for total elimination of the volumetric locking; 3) analysis of stability, convergence and accuracy of bES-FEM and bFS-FEM for nearly incompressible materials; 3) adaptive singular ES-FEM for singular field of arbitrary order; 4) extension to crystal plasticity problems; 4) thermos-elastic cracking; and 5) extension to saturated porous media. For the first time, S-FEM has been developed for solving fluid dynamics problems. A S-FEM is formulated for incompressible fluids that are common in various engineering systems. The new S-FEM fluid solver uses the Characteristic-Based Split (CBS) scheme to stabilize the solution in dealing with the coupled effects of convection and diffusion. This new S-FEM fluid solver works well with good accuracy and convergence, and it is a valuable alternative to the standard FEM for fluids. Moreover, when investigating the stabilization schemes for S-FEM, we have further devised a novel Characteristic-Based Penalty scheme using a selective node-based gradient smoothing operations, which worked well for the S-FEM formulation. A novel IS-FEM_FSI, where S-FEM is used for both fluids and solids, has been formulated, based on the immerse techniques for coupling of the fluids and heavily deformed moving solids. Verifications and validations of this newly developed IS-FEM_FSI have also been carried out. A number of techniques to enhance the efficiency of our IS-FEM_FSI have been developed, including the octree searching and point locating strategies that can significantly reduce the computational time for the information transfer on the FSI interfaces. In addition, multithreading has been implemented in our S-FEM algorithms. Finally, an IS-FEM_FSI code has been developed. The current code is capable of solving FSI problems with millions of fluid nodes with deformable structure immersed within, on a desktop computer. As a typical demonstration, we have successfully applied our IS-FEM_FSI code to simulate the hummingbird flapping process when it is hovering, with a relative large-scale model of about 2.5 millions of nodes. A video-clip of a computer simulated flapping hummingbird during hovering can be found at the PI?s webpage: http://www.ase.uc.edu/~liugr/. It shows not only the complex airflows structure around the bird, but also the stresses built on its wings that may undergo extremely large movement and deformation. The developed IS-FEM_FSI offers a novel technology for simulating computationally fluid-structural interaction problems, based on the S-FEM technology. It is an important addition and advancement from the currently widely used FEM technology. All these techniques developed in the project have either have been, are or will be published in international journals and conferences. The societal impact of this project is mainly on education of various levels. During this project one postdoc (part time) and three graduate students (part time) have been trained in this area important for the development of knowledge-based economy in US. In addition, one Co-op project has been offered to one of UC?s undergraduate students to participant in research work. This Co-op project has produced a US Patent that has been filed (provisional). Moreover, the outcome of this project will be used in the PI?s courses in the university at both undergraduate and graduate levels, aiming for long term and much broader educational outcomes. One seminar has been delivered at the Mason High School to generate interest in the young. The techniques, data and publications generated in the project has already been and will continuously be released to the general public and made available online for easy access. Currently, video demonstrations are made available at the PI?s public webpage http://www.ase.uc.edu/~liugr/, together with other related works by the team. The page is now constantly updated automatically by Google and vetted by the PI, so that the data is current and kept as accurate as possible. The list of constantly updated publications (including those from this project) can be openly found at any time at https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=uTsv5BcAAAAJ&hl=en.
